titleStmt.title: [Letter to the Secretary of the United Mexican Mining Association]

seriesStmt.title: übersetzt von Richard Heathfield, in: United Mexican Mining Association. Report of Don Lucas Alaman, Addressed to the Directors; Dated at Mexico, the 28th May, 1826; and a Letter from Baron de Humboldt, Addressed to the Secretary, London: Philanthropic Society 1826, S. 81–85.

div.p:
The Court of Directors having presented to
Baron de Humboldt, at Paris, a copy of their Report
of the 7th of September last, containing some ob-
servations by Mr. Alaman, on the Veta Madre of
Guanaxuato, in reference to the researches of the
Baron in that mineral district, the Baron addressed
the following Letter, distinguished by its urbanity,
candour, liberality and science, to the Secretary.
The Directors avail themselves of the earliest op-
portunity of publicly offering their thanks to M. de
Humboldt, for his great kindness, in thus acknow-
ledging a trifling mark of their attention and respect.

body.p:
“I am sensibly obliged by the kind and distinguished
mark of attention, which you and the Directors of the
United Mexican Mining Association, have been pleased to
confer upon me. Allow me, with the greatest respect, to
offer my thanks, and at the same time, to express my earnest
wishes for the success of an enterprize, tending, under so
many bearings, to the advancement of civilization. Your
‘Report’ highly merits to be taken as a model;—it is pre-
cise, candid, accompanied by very curious plans, and re-
plete with observations of much interest to the physical
sciences.

“I have long since expressed my doubts as to the general
applicability of steam engines in Mexico, and, I am con-
vinced, that rapid strides may be made in the science of
mining, without having recourse to such assistance, by ren-
dering more complete the machines at present in use, and
by introducing, where the fall of water is considerable,
machines à colonne d’eau; not such as are used in Hungary,
in Saxony, and at Moran, but such as are applied at the
salt works in Bavaria, and by Mr. Junger at Poulhaouenne,
in Britanny, constructed on Mr. Reichenbach’s principle,
and now made at Paris by Mr. Wilson, of 350 horse power,
without the great beam.

“In the person of Don Lucas Alaman, Secretary of
State to the Mexican Republic, your Association has all that
is to be expected from the union of high talent, most ex-
tensive information, and great elevation of character.

“How, Sir, could you entertain the idea, that from a
ridiculous pretension to infallibility, as a man of science, I
should be annoyed by the correction of my observations? I
am anxious for such corrections, and invite them in all my
writings. The somewhat decisive tone in which Mr.
Alaman announces my three ‘great mistakes,’ must be
ascribed merely to the habits of an exalted station. In the
discussion of facts it is not well to be particularly sensitive,
as to the tone of criticism. I am charged with holdingThese observations apply to the Veta Madre of Guanaxuato.—Translator. —
“First, That schistus occurs at the roof of the vein.

“Second, That at Santo Cristo de Burgos, the vein is
contracted to the thickness of half a metre.

“Third, That the plains of Temascatio, which are
lower than the bottom of Valenciana, seem to invite the
miner to engage in a work, which would at once answer the
purpose of carrying off the water and of facilitating the car-
riage of ore to the smelting and amalgamation works. (Vide
Essai Polit. edit. 4to. tom. ii. p. 528).

“I think, with Mr. Alaman, that the true relations of
the lode, where the porphyry and schistus are nearly con-
tiguous, are not yet sufficiently established; but can it be
laid down generally, that the metalliferous mass reposes on
schistus, and is covered by porphyry? That would be to make
it a bed instead of a lode. Can any spot be pointed out on
the N.W. where this superincumbent porphyry is to be found?
If there be no schistus in any part of the roof, what is the na-
ture of the schistus distinctly seen between Guanaxuato and
Valenciana, which, from the direction of the strata, and their
inclination to the S. W., must necessarily form part of the
roof, over the metalliferous mass? When we are in posses-
sion of plans, or geognostic sections of the Veta Madre, we
shall more easily comprehend Mr. Alaman’s view of these
relations. From a great number of analogous facts, ob-
served in Europe, it seems a probable inference, that the
porphyritic rocks, which appear to cover the schistus, in fact
pierce it, having been forced up from beneath. No one
has more opportunity than Mr. Alaman of throwing a
strong light on these facts;—even the practical miner must
feel interested in them, but no geognostic enquirer can fail
to hope, that Mr. Alaman will extend his memoir, and above
all, that he will accompany it by plans, founded on admea-
surement.

“As to the remarkable contraction of the Veta Madre
at Santo Cristo de Burgos, an opinion may be formed when
the water is drawn off. My statement was adopted on the
authority of miners, whom I consulted regarding the varia-
tions in the width of the lode, which in the mine of Valen-
ciana, is destitute of branches to the depth of 180 varas.

“I am of Mr. Alaman’s opinion, that it is not to be ex-
pected, in the present state of things, that the owners of
such a variety of works would undertake in concert, the ex-
cavation of an immense tunnel from the plains of Temascatio,
or the ravine of Marfil, to be employed both as an adit to
carry off the water, and for the purpose of conveying the ore
to the reduction works; but when we see, in a poor country,
like Saxony, an adit of the length of 207,400 feet English,
it is surely allowable to say, that the vicinity of these plains
seems to invite a work, the effects of which, were the whole of
the Veta Madre of Guanaxuato, the property of a single Com-
pany, open to enlarged views, would be incalculable.

“I was only one month at Guanaxuato; I descended al-
most daily into the mines; I studied the order of super-
position of the formations, upon the geognostic principles
which prevailed in the first years of this century; I carried
the barometer to all the heights; I made astronomical ob-
servations, and others on the magnetic inclination, dip and
intensity; I accumulated statistic materials; I communi-
cated with miners, and all persons of cultivated mind who
honoured me with their attention; and, in fine, I be-
lieve I did all that could be accomplished, by an active man,
in the short space of thirty days, passed between Guanaxuato,
the Sierra of Santa Rosa, and Comangillas. I hope, most
sincerely, that the accomplished geologists, now at Valen-
ciana and Rayas, will soon supply us with a trigonometric
survey of the environs of Guanaxuato, and sections of the
strata. Such a work would supersede the very imperfect
sketch which I have traced, as fully as the noble map, by my
learned and respectable friend Don Felipe’ Bauza will, I
hope, supply the place of my imperfect and incomplete map
of Mexico.

salute.hi:
I have the honour to be,
With the greatest consideration,
Sir,
Your very humble and obedient servant,
Alexandre Humboldt.”
